text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
CCDM 30.4.2.5.1 was updated to reﬂect the change in delegation of authority from the Chief to the Associate Chief Counsel (F&M) to approve Quality Step Increases (QSI).
Chief Counsel
Table of Contents
Guidance
) This section provides information on probationary and trial periods, within- grade increases, performance-based actions, and the awards program. for Chief (
) The following subsections establish policy and procedures within the Office Chief Counsel for probationary and trial periods. and Periods (
) The Office of Personnel Management (OPM) provides no requirements governing the separation of employees occupying excepted positions for trial periods. (
) To the extent practicable, it is the policy of the Office of Chief Counsel to employees in trial periods the same as those in probationary periods. (

) All attorneys, regardless of grade, who are serving their ﬁrst year of ment with the Office of Chief Counsel are considered to be in a one year period. The one year trial period begins with the date of appointment to an attorney (
series) or law clerk (
series) position and is completed one year after the date of the appointment. (
) Supervisors should involve the Labor and Employee Relations staff in the stage of a potential termination of an attorney in a trial period. (
) A formal progress review, which entails completion of Form
, Appraisal (LD-
CC/IRS), (or some other written document) is required through the trial period. Approving officials may request more frequent (

) Appraisals on attorneys serving in a trial period are due no earlier than the beginning of the ninth month and no later than the end of the tenth month, the appropriate Assistant Chief Counsel or Area Counsel. This time frame assumes that the attorney has been under elements and standards at least days. (
) However, if at any time during the
-month trial period, it appears that an attorney is performing below acceptable standards, it is desirable for the attorney to be promptly informed of the problem by their immediate (
) The attorneys should be given a fair opportunity to perform at acceptable standards, and should have been put on notice that performance is below ceptable standards. (

) If the performance has been below acceptable standards and the appraisal does not reﬂect the likelihood of sufficient improvement, a discussion held with the attorney in which he/she is given the option of either leaving Office of Chief Counsel voluntarily (by resignation) or having the Office of Counsel initiate action for involuntary separation. At this point, the may elect one of the following alternatives: a. He/she may wish to discuss their performance with a higher level of pervision. b. He/she may wish to resign during the trial period; if so, he/she will be released from the employment commitment tenure.
To the extent practicable, it is the policy of the Office of Chief Counsel to employees in trial periods the same as those in probationary periods.
He/she may wish to discuss their performance with a higher level of su
pervision. He/she may wish to resign during the trial period; if so, he/she will be released from the employment commitment tenure.

Personnel Administration, Training, and Employment Opportunity c. He/she may decline to resign. In this case, the supervisor should with Labor and Employee Relations and with the appropriate official authorized to terminate an attorney (typically an Associate Counsel or Division Counsel) on how to proceed further. (

) In addition to performance, an attorney, at the discretion of the Office of Counsel, may be separated during the trial period for the following • Conduct before his/her appointment, such as the intentional of application forms or pre-appointment documents (usually the information discovered during the attorney’s background • Conduct after appointment, such as violation of rules of conduct (

) Allegations that a separation during the trial period was based on race, religion, age, gender, national origin, political affiliation, disability, sexual Rights tation, marital, or parental status should be processed under Chief discrimination complaint procedures as described in CCDM
, Employment Opportunity, Complaints of Discrimination. (
) New non-attorney employees, who have not completed a full one-year tionary period in the federal government, serve subject to completion of a Period for year probationary period. Employees (

) During the probationary period, the supervisor should closely observe the employee and decide whether: a. The employee’s abilities and proﬁciency conforms to office standards. b. The employee’s personality traits (i.e., cooperation, adaptability, and emotional stability) are satisfactory. c. The employee has the potential for successful Government work. d. The employee has displayed conduct problems. (
) If the probationer does not meet these standards, the supervisor should recommend their separation as soon as this determination is made. (

) If, after a reasonable period, it is apparent that an employee is not suited continued employment, he/she will be separated. There is no minimum for for a trial period — it is whatever amount of time it takes for a supervisor evaluate the employee’s performance and conduct and to arrive at a or Conduct whether he/she should be retained or separated. After (

) A written notice issued by an individual with the delegated authority must issued in order to separate a probationer. Although not required, it is good management practice to provide the employee with

days’ advance separation. A lesser notice period can be established if circumstances This notice must contain at least: a. The office’s conclusions on the inadequacies of the employee’s mance or conduct b. The effective date of the action c. A statement explaining the limited appeal rights to the Merit Systems tection Board (MSPB) under
CFR §

Personnel Administration, Training, and Equal Employment Opportunity
In addition to performance, an attorney, at the discretion of the Office of Chief Counsel, may be separated during the trial period for the following reasons:

a. The office’s conclusions on the inadequacies of the employee’s perfor- mance or conduct b. The effective date of the action c. A statement explaining the limited appeal rights to the Merit Systems Pro- tection Board (MSPB) under
CFR §
Guidance

) The Office of Chief Counsel may separate an employee for reasons whole or in part on their conduct before employment, such as the for Conduct falsiﬁcation of application forms or other pre-appointment documents. This Before action must be taken by an official with the delegated authority. (
) When the separation action is proposed, the employee is entitled to an advance written notice which contains the speciﬁc and detailed reasons action. A
-day advance notice period is recommended for most cases. (
) The advance written notice must:
Give the reasons, in simple, detailed terms, so the employee is able understand and reply to them
Inform the employee that he/she may reply in writing and submit vits in support of their reply
Identify the person or office to receive the reply and state a time frame for preparing and returning the reply (

) Following the consideration of any oral or written reply, the employee is to notiﬁcation of the decision as soon as practicable. This written must: a. Be delivered at or before the time the decision becomes effective b. Inform the employee of the reasons for the action c. Contain a statement explaining the limited appeal rights to the MSPB under
CFR §
) Further information regarding removals for conduct occurring before ment may be obtained from the Labor and Employee Relations Division. (
CFR §
explains the limited appeal rights to the MSPB for ary employees. Rights (

) Appeals based solely on race, color, religion, age, gender, national origin, political affiliation, disability, sexual orientation, marital, or parental status should be processed under Chief Counsel’s discrimination complaint dures as described in CCDM
, Equal Employment Opportunity, plaints of Discrimination. (

) This subsection provides procedures on use of the probationary period for attorney, competitive service employees who are assigned to supervisory Period for managerial positions. This probationary period allows management to and the performance of new supervisors or managers and provides an avenue returning the employee to a non-supervisory or non-managerial position without using adverse action procedures. (

) Probationary periods for new appointments take precedence over or supervisory probationary periods. If an employee is subject to both, tion of the new-appointment probationary period meets the requirements both periods. (
) The Office of the Associate Chief Counsel (Finance and Management) is sponsible for: During Period

) The employee’s immediate supervisor is responsible for: a. Establishing and discussing written performance requirements with employees serving a probationary period within

calendar days after entering the affected position b. Ensuring that the employee is provided adequate regarding progress during the probationary period c. Initiating a recommendation to return the employee to a or non-managerial position at any time during the probationary period deﬁciencies in performance warrant this recommendation (

) Vacancy announcements for positions subject to a probationary period will contain the following statement: Employees to “An individual selected for this position who has not satisfactorily completed a managerial/supervisory probationary period must do so. Failure to satisfactorily complete the probationary period will result in being returned to a position of no lower grade and pay than the position held before selection.”

“An individual selected for this position who has not satisfactorily completed a managerial/supervisory probationary period must do so. Failure to satisfactorily complete the probationary period will result in being returned to a position of no lower grade and pay than the position held before selection.” (

) Employees must be given written notice that they will be returned to a non- managerial or non-supervisory position before the effective date. The notice must include sufficient factual information to support the action. (

) When an employee is returned to a lower-graded position, the pay is set at level in the lower grade the employee would have attained if he/she had remained in that position. Grade and pay retention rights do not apply. (

) An employee who accepts a lower grade to enter a managerial or position and does not successfully complete the probationary period must: a. Be re-promoted to the grade previously held, which may be at any depending on the needs of the Office b. Receive the salary he/she would have attained had he/she stayed at higher grade, including within-grade increases (
) Decisions to return employees to their previous or a like position are not grievable and there is no right of appeal. (
) Employees may contest whether they are subject to a probationary period through the Chief Counsel’s agency grievance procedure. There is no right appeal.

“An individual selected for this position who has not satisfactorily completed a managerial/supervisory probationary period must do Failure to satisfactorily complete the probationary period will result being returned to a position of no lower grade and pay than the position held before selection.”

) Employees removed from a managerial or supervisory position who believe action was based on discrimination due to race, color, religion, age, gender, national origin, political affiliation, disability, sexual orientation, marital, or parental status may ﬁle a discrimination complaint under the Chief discrimination complaint procedures described in CCDM
, Equal ployment Opportunity, Complaints of Discrimination. (
) Allegations of discrimination based on marital status or partisan political tion are appealable to the Merit Systems Protection Board. These appeals must be ﬁled within
calendar days of the action. (
) A full- or part-time employee of the Office of Chief Counsel who occupies a permanent position and has not reached the maximum rate of pay for their grade level (step

) will be advanced to the next higher step provided: a. He/she has completed the required waiting period, which varies on the within-grade step already attained For Steps Weeks of creditable service in the next lower step

) during the waiting period. Note: A high-quality increase is not considered an equivalent increase. (

) The waiting period for a within-grade increase begins: • On the ﬁrst appointment as an employee of the Federal regardless of tenure • On receiving a promotion or an equivalent increase • After a period of non-pay status or break in service (alone or in nation) in excess of
calendar weeks, unless the non-pay status break in service is creditable (i.e., military service) (
) A within-grade increase is effective the ﬁrst day of the ﬁrst pay period follows the completion of the required waiting period. (

) Acceptable level of competence for within-grade increase purposes means level of performance of assigned work of at least Fully Successful, i.e., the of rating of record or composite rating score equates to a ﬁnal summary rating Fully Successful or better. (

) An employee’s acceptable level of competence determination will be postponed when either of the following conditions are met: a. He/she has not been advised of, and has not worked under, their elements and standards for at least
days (a requirement of the Chief Counsel Directives Manual

(06-12-2006) Acceptable Level of Competence Determinations

days in the new position. (
) No speciﬁc written notice is required if an employee is given a positive able level of competence determination. (

) The employee’s most recent rating of record must support any decision to grant or withhold a within-grade increase. When a within-grade decision is consistent with the employee’s most recent rating of record, a more current rating of record must be prepared. (

) When the supervisor determines the employee’s performance is not at an ceptable level of competence for a within-grade increase, the supervisor Determinations notify the employee in writing. This notice will: a. Give the reasons for the negative determination and the speciﬁc areas which the employee must improve their performance in order to be granted a within-grade increase b. Inform the employee of their right to request that the determination be considered by an appropriate agency official (usually the next highest supervisor), within
calendar days from receipt of the negative nation (
) When a negative determination is issued, the employee, or their personal resentative, may request a reconsideration of the determination. The procedures will be followed as established in
CFR §
) The employee or their representative must request reconsideration of a negative determination in writing within

calendar days from receipt of negative determination. This request may be made to the official who made determination or to the reconsideration official. The written request must contain the reasons why the determination should be reconsidered. (
) An employee in a duty status will be granted a reasonable amount of time to review the material used to support the negative determination and prepare a response to the determination. (
) The agency official must provide the employee with a prompt written ﬁnal decision (usually within
calendar days). (

) When a negative determination is sustained after reconsideration, the employee will be informed in writing of the reasons for the decision. The employee will also be informed of their right to appeal the decision to the MSPB. (
) Further information on appeal rights regarding acceptable level of determinations is found in

which the employee must improve their performance in order to be granted a within-grade increase b. Inform the employee of their right to request that the determination considered by an appropriate agency official (usually the next highest supervisor), within

The employee or their representative must request reconsideration of a negative determination in writing within

calendar days from receipt of negative determination. This request may be made to the official who determination or to the reconsideration official. The written request must contain the reasons why the determination should be reconsidered. An employee in a duty status will be granted a reasonable amount of time to review the material used to support the negative determination prepare a response to the determination. The agency official must provide the employee with a prompt written ﬁnal decision (usually within

calendar days). When a negative determination is sustained after reconsideration, the employee will be informed in writing of the reasons for the decision. The employee will also be informed of their right to appeal the decision to the MSPB. Further information on appeal rights regarding acceptable level of determinations is found in
CFR §

The employee or their representative must request reconsideration of a negative determination in writing within 15 calendar days from receipt of the negative determination. This request may be made to the official who made the determination or to the reconsideration official. The written request must contain the reasons why the determination should be reconsidered.
Further information on appeal rights regarding acceptable level of competence determinations is found in 5 CFR § 531.410.
Guidance

) After a within-grade has been withheld, the employee may be granted the within-grade increase at any time after the supervisor determines the has demonstrated sustained performance at an acceptable level of a tence. At a minimum, the supervisor must determine if the employee’s Increase performance is at an acceptable level of competence after each
weeks following the original due date of the within-grade increase. (

) An employee should not be retained indeﬁnitely in a position in which their formance is below an acceptable level of competence. If an employee not bring their performance up to an acceptable level within a year, the should consider steps such as reassignment, demotion, or removal. (

) When a negative determination has been issued and the supervisor later certiﬁes that the employee has achieved a sustained level of competence, of within-grade increase is effective the ﬁrst day of the pay period following Increase new determination. (
) If the reconsideration process results in the employee receiving a increase, the effective date of the within-grade increase is retroactive to original due date. (

) When a determination has been postponed, but the supervisor certiﬁes employee’s acceptable level of competence at the end of the period, the effective date of the within-grade increase is retroactive to the original due date. (

) When a supervisor is considering a negative determination or a of a within-grade increase, he/she should immediately contact the Labor Employee Relations staff for assistance, including assistance in drafting all for notices to employees regarding within-grade increases mentioned in this a section. Increase (

) Within-grade increases are automatically generated the pay period before effective date. In order for the within-grade to be withheld timely, the personnel office must take action to stop the automatic processing. This cation should be at least one full pay period in advance of the effective is important that the supervisor work closely with the servicing personnel on postponements and negative determinations so the within-grade is not matically generated. (
) The Office of Chief Counsel uses a ﬁve-level system for assessing perfor- mance of employees. The ﬁve levels are: • Outstanding (
) Grade or • Excellent/Exceeds Fully Successful (
) • Fully Successful (
) • Minimally Successful (
) • Unacceptable (

) A Critical Element is a component of a position consisting of one or more duties and responsibilities that contributes toward accomplishing goals and objectives and that is of such importance that unacceptable mance in the element would result in overall unacceptable performance in position. (
) Chief Counsel Directives Manual
(06-12-2006) Performance-Based Reduction in Grade or Removal Actions
Personnel Administration, Training, and Employment Opportunity (

) Opportunity to demonstrate acceptable performance (also referred to as an “opportunity period”, “performance improvement plan” or “PIP”) means a rea- sonable chance for an employee whose performance has been determined be unacceptable in one or more critical elements to demonstrate acceptable performance in the critical element(s) at issue. (
) Unacceptable performance means performance that fails to meet established performance standards in one or more critical elements of such employee’s position. (

) This subsection covers reductions-in-grade and removals based solely on acceptable performance by employees who have completed a probationary/ trial period. For employees in the bargaining unit, appropriate contract provisions related to subjects in this section must be reviewed. In cases of conﬂict with this section, the collective bargaining agreement will prevail. (

) The Chief Counsel delegation orders contain delegations of authority about personnel issues to Associate Chief Counsels and Division Counsels, the lowest levels to which such authority can be re-delegated. An official rized to propose a performance based action cannot be below such level. Further, an official who decides if such action should be taken must be at one level above the organizational level of the proposing official. See CCDM
, Delegations of Authority and Designations. (

) When documenting an employee’s unacceptable performance, the supervisor may be asked to determine the employee’s acceptable level of competence a within-grade increase. When an acceptable level of competence tion is due and an action based on unacceptable performance is the level of competence determination should be “unable to certify”. (

) When an employee exhibits a pattern of performance indicating deﬁciencies a critical element(s), the supervisor should counsel the employee. Speciﬁc Counseling items in support of the deﬁciencies should be discussed with the employee. is recommended that this counseling session be documented by the in writing and a copy given to the employee. (

) If the employee indicates, or the supervisor suspects, that the employee’s formance deﬁciencies are the result of, or have been affected by, alcoholism, drug dependency, emotional problems, family pressure, or other problems of personal nature, the supervisor should refer the employee to the Employee Assistance Program (EAP) for counseling and assistance as appropriate. mation about the EAP program can be obtained through the Labor and Employee Relations staff. (

) If the employee’s performance does not improve after the counseling session(s), the supervisor should determine whether the employee’s perfor- Period mance is unacceptable. If so, the supervisor should consider placing the employee on an opportunity period/performance improvement plan. (

) An opportunity period begins with the delivery of a letter to the employee notifying the employee about the performance problems and how intends to assist the employee with these issues. The letter should include: Chief Counsel Directives Manual Cat. No.
E
Personnel Administration, Training, and Equal Employment Opportunity

) Opportunity to demonstrate acceptable performance (also referred to as an “opportunity period”, “performance improvement plan” or “PIP”) means a rea- sonable chance for an employee whose performance has been determined to be unacceptable in one or more critical elements to demonstrate acceptable performance in the critical element(s) at issue. (
) Unacceptable performance means performance that fails to meet established performance standards in one or more critical elements of such employee’s position. (

) This subsection covers reductions-in-grade and removals based solely on un- acceptable performance by employees who have completed a probationary/ trial period. For employees in the bargaining unit, appropriate contract provisions related to subjects in this section must be reviewed. In cases of conﬂict with this section, the collective bargaining agreement will prevail. (

) The Chief Counsel delegation orders contain delegations of authority about personnel issues to Associate Chief Counsels and Division Counsels, the lowest levels to which such authority can be re-delegated. An official rized to propose a performance based action cannot be below such level. Further, an official who decides if such action should be taken must be at one level above the organizational level of the proposing official. See CCDM
, Delegations of Authority and Designations. (

) When documenting an employee’s unacceptable performance, the supervisor may be asked to determine the employee’s acceptable level of competence a within-grade increase. When an acceptable level of competence determina- tion is due and an action based on unacceptable performance is the level of competence determination should be “unable to certify”.

a. The critical element(s) and performance standard(s) which are able and the performance requirements or standards that must be in order to demonstrate acceptable performance b. The exact nature of the deﬁciencies (supporting documents illustrating deﬁciencies may be used) c. The fact that failure to become at least minimally successful or failure sustain that level of performance for the one year following the start of opportunity period (or performance improvement plan) may result in a proposal to downgrade the employee or separate the employee from Federal service d. The speciﬁc period of time given to demonstrate acceptable The supervisor determines this time based on complexity of the duties, length of experience in the position, prior performance record, training, and any other relevant factors. In most cases sixty to ninety days be sufficient period to demonstrate acceptable performance. e. The supervisor’s commitment to work with the employee and a general description of what this commitment will entail f. The right to have the agency consider any medical condition which believes contributed to their performance problem (
) Supervisors should contact Labor and Employee Relations for assistance in drafting an opportunity period letter. (
) If the employee’s performance becomes acceptable during the opportunity period (or performance improvement period), he/she should be advised in writing. (

) If the employee’s performance during the opportunity period is the supervisor must consider (in consultation with the official with the authority to propose such action and Labor and Employee Relations) the the employee’s demotion or removal should be proposed. (

) Supervisors may also consider alternatives such as: • Reassignment. For example, assignment back to a former or similar position may be considered when an employee has accepted a reas- signment to a new position and encounters performance problems in the new position. • Voluntary Reduction in Grade. If an employee acknowledges an to fulﬁll the responsibilities of their position, he/she may be placed in position he/she voluntarily requests (either at the same or lower However, a position must be available, the employee qualiﬁed and suitable for the position, and the Office must reasonably determine the employee will be able to satisfactorily perform in that position. • Retirement/Disability Retirement. If an employee is eligible to retire the performance problems appear related to a disability), the may want to raise the possibility of retirement before recommending separation of the employee from the position occupied. However, it be clear that it is the employee’s choice whether or not to pursue ment. (
) An employee whose reduction in grade or removal is proposed is
a. The critical element(s) and performance standard(s) which are unaccept

able and the performance requirements or standards that must be attained in order to demonstrate acceptable performance b. The exact nature of the deﬁciencies (supporting documents illustrating the deﬁciencies may be used) c. The fact that failure to become at least minimally successful or failure to sustain that level of performance for the one year following the start of the opportunity period (or performance improvement plan) may result in a proposal to downgrade the employee or separate the employee from the Federal service d. The speciﬁc period of time given to demonstrate acceptable performance. The supervisor determines this time based on complexity of the duties, length of experience in the position, prior performance record, training, and any other relevant factors. In most cases sixty to ninety days should be sufficient period to demonstrate acceptable performance. e. The supervisor’s commitment to work with the employee and a general description of what this commitment will entail f. The right to have the agency consider any medical condition which he/she believes contributed to their performance problem Supervisors should contact Labor and Employee Relations for assistance in drafting an opportunity period letter. If the employee’s performance becomes acceptable during the opportunity period (or performance improvement period), he/she should be advised in writing.
Reassignment. For example, assignment back to a former or similar position may be considered when an employee has accepted a reas

signment to a new position and encounters performance problems in the new position. Voluntary Reduction in Grade. If an employee acknowledges an inability to fulﬁll the responsibilities of their position, he/she may be placed in a position he/she voluntarily requests (either at the same or lower grade). However, a position must be available, the employee qualiﬁed and suitable for the position, and the Office must reasonably determine that the employee will be able to satisfactorily perform in that position. Retirement/Disability Retirement. If an employee is eligible to retire (or if the performance problems appear related to a disability), the supervisor may want to raise the possibility of retirement before recommending separation of the employee from the position occupied. However, it must be clear that it is the employee’s choice whether or not to pursue retire
ment.

Personnel Administration, Training, and Employment Opportunity • Thirty calendar days advance written notice stating speciﬁc instances unacceptable performance on which the proposed action is based the critical element(s) involved in each instance of unacceptable mance. The performance standard(s) should also be listed under the unacceptable critical element(s). • Representation by an attorney or other representative • A reasonable time to answer orally and in writing • A ﬁnal written decision that either sustains, mitigates a proposed removal to a reduction in grade, or withdraws the proposed action. ﬁnal decision should be issued to the employee within
days after expiration of the advance notice period. (

) All employees are entitled to choose a representative. However, the tative may not be an individual whose priority work assignments would preclude their release from their official duties or whose activities as a repre- sentative would: • Cause a conﬂict of interest or position • Give rise to unreasonable costs to the government (

) An employee who wants the Office to consider a medical condition which have contributed to their unacceptable or below fully successful should submit this information when he/she is placed on an opportunity However, this information must be submitted not later than the time limits allowed for the oral and written replies. (
) If an employee is under the Civil Service Retirement System (CSRS) and ﬁve years of civilian service, or under the Federal Employees Retirement System (FERS) and has

months of civilian service, the Office will supply information on disability retirement. It should be noted that applications for ability retirement do not preclude or delay appropriate personnel actions. In certain limited circumstances, the Office may initiate a disability retirement an employee and Labor and Employee Relations should be consulted for advice on such matters. (
) Supervisors should consult with Labor and Employee Relations for in drafting an advance notice of proposed action based on unacceptable per- Proposed formance. (

advance notice and that any replies submitted will be given full consider- ation m. A statement that the employee will be notiﬁed in writing of the ﬁnal decision n. A statement regarding the work status of the employee during the notice period (
) An employee has a right to reply personally to the proposed action. (
) If an employee chooses to make an oral reply, a verbatim transcript will be made. (

) Ordinarily, the oral reply will take place at the employee’s post of duty. When this is not practical, the oral reply will be scheduled at a location that will minimize travel expense for the employee and the representative. (

) The proposing official, whenever possible, will serve as the oral reply officer. If it is impractical, the proposing official may designate another manager within the same organizational unit who must be of a higher grade and/or rank than the employee making the oral reply. The oral reply officer’s primary function is to: • Listen • Encourage an open and frank presentation • Conduct an orderly proceeding • Develop and clarify by judicious, non-provocative questions factual matters on which a fair determination can be made (

) The oral reply officer must avoid any appearance or inference that the oral reply is a hearing or adversary proceeding. Instead, questions to the making the oral reply should be framed to elicit information and it is not necessary for the oral reply officer to justify the reasons contained in the of proposed action. ) The decision notice should include the following: a. The date of previous advance notice of proposed action based on ceptable performance b. A reference to any and all replies made by the employee and a that these replies were considered. If the employee made no replies, decision notice should reﬂect that fact c. The determination reached on each reasons and speciﬁcation in the proposed action, i.e., whether each is sustained or not sustained d. The nature of the action to be taken e. The effective date of the action. The effective date of the action must follow the employee’s receipt of the decision notice. ) In the event the employee is not removed or reduced in grade due to performance during the opportunity to improve but there are future perfor- mance problems within one year from the beginning of the opportunity the supervisor should consult with Labor and Employee Relations. (

) An employee who has been removed or reduced in grade under these dures may appeal to the MSPB, if one of the following conditions is satisﬁed: a. He/she is in the competitive service and has completed a probationary trial period b. He/she is in the competitive service serving in an appointment which not require a probationary or trial period and has completed one year of current continuous employment in the same or similar positions under other than a temporary appointment of one year or less c. He/she is a preference eligible employee in the excepted service who completed one year of current continuous employment in the same or similar position(s) d. He/she is a non-preference eligible employee in the excepted service has completed two years of current continuous service in the same or similar positions in an Executive agency under other than a temporary pointment limited to two years or less. (
) A bargaining unit employee who has been removed or reduced in grade due unacceptable performance and meets one of the categories listed under paragraph (
) may appeal to the MSPB or invoke arbitration under the ated agreement with consent of the Union. An employee cannot do both. (

) A non-preference eligible employee in the excepted service who lacks two years of current continuous service in the same or similar positions in an Executive agency in other than a temporary appointment limited to two years or less, and is not serving a trial period may appeal removal and reduction in grade decisions through the Chief Counsel agency grievance procedures in CCDM
, Labor and Employee Relations. (

) The Office of Chief Counsel Awards Program is a part of the Treasury ment’s Awards Program and shares the Department’s purpose of recognizing employees for their contributions to the improvement of government opera- tions. In addition to Treasury awards, incentive awards, Secretarial Honor awards, and external awards, the Office of Chief Counsel has implemented several special and honor award categories over the years. . One such category, the National Awards, presents awards to employees who have ac- complished a special achievement and performed their assigned duties at a sustained level of excellence. In addition, the Employee Suggestion Awards are given to those employees who have created and/or implemented a while suggestion. (
) The Awards Program outlined in this subsection will be the only awards program for Chief Counsel. All policies concerning awards and special tion for achievement are contained in this section. (
) The Awards Program covers all Chief Counsel employees at GS/GM-
and below. SES awards recommendations and approval are subject to the and procedures of the Performance Review Board. (
) It is the policy of Chief Counsel that: Chief Counsel Directives Manual

a. He/she is in the competitive service and has completed a probationary or trial period b. He/she is in the competitive service serving in an appointment which not require a probationary or trial period and has completed one year of current continuous employment in the same or similar positions under other than a temporary appointment of one year or less c. He/she is a preference eligible employee in the excepted service who has completed one year of current continuous employment in the same or similar position(s) d. He/she is a non

preference eligible employee in the excepted service has completed two years of current continuous service in the same or similar positions in an Executive agency under other than a temporary pointment limited to two years or less.

Personnel Administration, Training, and Employment Opportunity • Awards will be given timely • Awards will be uniformly and fairly distributed nationwide • Awards will have an established maximum and minimum amount on category (

) Associate Chief Counsel/Division Counsel are responsible for administering Awards Program for their employees, except in the case of the National Awards which will be administered annually at the National level. (

) Associate Chief Counsel/Division Counsel may establish additional non- monetary awards for their employees. The non-monetary awards should be the form of special certiﬁcates limited in scope so as not to detract from the signiﬁcance and importance of the nationwide awards program. Award programs established must be submitted through the Deputy Chief Counsel (Operations) for approval by the Chief Counsel prior to implementation. The certiﬁcates attached to these awards should be procured locally, signed by Associate Chief Counsel/Division Counsel, and presented at any time. (
) Cash awards and quality step increases are an integral part of the Chief Counsel Awards Program. Supervisors should consider all alternatives when making recommendations. (
) Nominations may be initiated using Form
, Recommendation for tion, at any supervisory level for the various awards in the Awards Program and must be submitted by or approved by Associate Chief Counsel/Division Counsel. (

) Award nominations based on a particular case must be free of all references a taxpayer and the issues involved in the taxpayer’s case in order to avoid intentional disclosure of tax-related information. In most cases, it will not be necessary to attach a copy of a brief or other legal document to the nomina- tion. If, for some reason, the recommending official believes that it is critical that the approving official be aware of the identity of the taxpayer and/or the issue, a separate memorandum may be attached as an appendix to the nation. (
) Associate Chief Counsel/Division Counsel may approve and give incentive, career service, and local awards. (

) Associate Chief Counsel/Division Counsel must submit formal recommenda- tions for certain types of awards, such as Treasury Awards and Quality Step Increases (QSI). The Chief Counsel must approve Treasury Awards and ents should not be advised of their nomination prior to notiﬁcation of the Counsel’s approval. The Associate Chief Counsel (F&M) may approve QSI recipients should not be advised of the recommendation prior to approval. (
) Awardees will receive monetary and non-monetary recognition as indicated the Associate Chief Counsel/Division Counsel or by the Associate Chief Counsel (F&M). (

) Nomination Procedures for National Awards: Annually, the Associate Chief Counsel (F&M) will distribute a call memo for award nominations. This memo will include speciﬁc directions for submission. Nomination Procedures for National Awards: Annually, the Associate Chief Counsel (F&M) will distribute a call memo for award nominations. This memo will include speciﬁc directions for submission. An individual can be nominated for more than one national award, but may not receive more than one national

award annually. Supervisory/managerial employees may be considered for non-supervisory awards based on substantive work in the appropriate area. Award recipients will be selected by a group of ﬁve individuals ing the Office and appointed by the Chief Counsel. (

) Each year the total amount available for awards will be determined by the Deputy Chief Counsel (Operations) in consultation with the Associate Chief Counsel (F&M). The allocation to each Associate Chief Counsel/Division Counsel for local and incentive awards will be based on the ratio of salary dollars to total salary dollars, excluding SES. The Deputy Chief Counsel (Op- erations) will communicate the award allocations to each Associate Chief Counsel/Division Counsel. (
) Associate Chief Counsel/Division Counsel will establish maximum and minimum award amounts for incentive and local awards. Each National has a prescribed dollar amount. (

) In order to provide uniformity, Associate Chief Counsel/Division Counsel may establish award submission due dates within their business unit (unless otherwise speciﬁed in the description of the award). (

) Associate Chief Counsel/Division Counsel should procure award certiﬁcates incentive, career service, and local awards. Certiﬁcates will be signed and presented by Associate Chief Counsel/Division Counsel. (

) Associate Chief Counsel/Division Counsel is encouraged to make appropriate arrangements for ceremonious recognition of employees. The National will be presented by the Chief Counsel at an annual ceremony in the Office. (

) Associate Chief Counsel/Division Counsel should submit a copy of each approved award, even non-monetary awards, to the Associate Chief Counsel (F&M). This information is needed to satisfy recurring outside reporting ments. (

) The Albert Gallatin Award is conferred upon retirement to employees who twenty or more years in Treasury, and whose record reﬂects ﬁdelity to duty. Awardees receive a certiﬁcate and a biographical sketch of Albert Gallatin. Human Resources Division will request this award for eligible employees in Headquarters office. Associate Chief Counsel (F&M) employees servicing Counsel offices will follow the procedures established by IRS. (

) The Associate Chief Counsel/Division Counsel will follow the procedures and criteria outlined in the solicitation memorandum issued for the nomination for the Legal Division Annual Awards given by the General Counsel to recognize particularly outstanding performance by Treasury attorneys and such as: • The Lonkay Award, which recognizes GS-

or higher attorneys who have at least ten years of service as an attorney with the Federal gov- ernment and who have demonstrated extraordinary dedication and professional expertise in the performance of their duties over the past ﬁve years

) This subsection provides information about the four types of incentive in the Office of Chief Counsel. (

) A performance award is given to employees for high-level performance of duties as reﬂected in the most recent rating of record. This type of is appropriate when the employee’s performance clearly shows that their overall performance has substantially exceeded acceptable job Awardees receive a lump sum cash payment and a certiﬁcate. (

) A Quality Step Increase (QSI) may be given in those circumstances where employee’s performance exceeds that rewarded by a performance award. Since a QSI increases an employee’s rate of basic pay through an within-grade increase, it should be given to recognize and reward who display continuing outstanding performance. A QSI may only be given upon the written approval of the Associate Chief Counsel (F&M). (

) Careful consideration should be given to each nomination for a quality step increase. It may be granted only when: a. An employee received a summary performance rating at the highest on their most recent appraisal b. It is known that the employee will remain in the position, or in a similar position at the same grade level in which his or her performance can expected to continue at the same level of effectiveness, for at least
days from the date of the award c. The employee has not received a quality step increase within the preceding
consecutive calendar weeks (
) The decision to grant a QSI to an employee must be supported by a mental written statement setting forth the reasons for granting the QSI when the appraisal is more than
days old. (

) A special act award is appropriate when an employee, or group of performs beyond expectations on a speciﬁc assignment or aspect of an as- signment or job function. The special act must have been connected with or related to official employment, in the public interest, and so signiﬁcant that special recognition is justiﬁed. (
) Chief Counsel Directives Manual

It is known that the employee will remain in the position, or in a position at the same grade level in which his or her performance can expected to continue at the same level of effectiveness, for at least days from the date of the award c. The employee has not received a quality step increase within the preceding

Employment Opportunity (

) A special act is a single action or series of actions of relatively short duration either within or outside the normal duties performed by the employee(s) and differs from superior performance since sustained overall performance is not involved. (

) The Employee Suggestion Program provides employees with the opportunity submit constructive proposals that identify and describe a speciﬁc need for provement, and propose a solution. If the suggestion is adopted after evaluation of the proposal, the employee may receive an award. (
) Further information on the Employee Suggestion Program may be found in CCDM
, Programs and Special Topics. (
) Local awards recognize employees within their Associate Chief Counsel/ Division Counsel area. Each business unit deﬁnes the criteria for their Local Awards Program. (

) External awards are monetary and non-monetary awards sponsored by zations external to Treasury, such as the Innovations in American Award from the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard and the Younger Federal Lawyer Award from the Federal Bar Association. vidual nomination requests are solicited throughout the year.

The Employee Suggestion Program provides employees with the opportunity to submit constructive proposals that identify and describe a speciﬁc need for im- provement, and propose a solution. If the suggestion is adopted after evaluation of the proposal, the employee may receive an award.
Excellence Awards
(cid:129) Number: 1 award
(cid:129) Eligibility: All non-management attorneys and tax law specialists. An employee may not be given both this and another national award in the same ﬁscal year.

(cid:129) Award Criteria: The employee’s performance must be the most exemplary of the Speciﬁcally, the candidate must possess professional excellence, leadership, and character, and have made especially noteworthy contributions to the Office’s role as counsel to the Internal Revenue Service. Exhibit 30.4.2-1 (Cont. 4) (11-18-2011) Chief Counsel National Awards
Innovation (Technology, Work Process) – Chief Counsel Donald Korb
Number: 4 awards ((three legal and one non-legal)
Eligibility: All employees

Criteria: Given to recognize an individual who has demonstrated or created innovation the use of technology or improved business processes. It is anticipated that the activity would beneﬁt the office beyond the employee’s immediate work area or a model for adoption by other offices. The act for which they are nominated should outside normal performance and should not be recurring in nature. The act should a signiﬁcant contribution, special achievement, or cost savings to the Office.
Amount: Up to $2,500 each

Award Criteria: Given to an attorney that has successfully reached across lines within Counsel or into other agencies to form new connections or enhanced working relations. It is anticipated that the effort would be more than the normal coordination required by current work procedures. For example, reaching across Counsel lines (two or more division counsel, two or more associate chief counsel; division counsel and associate chief counsel; creating new intra-Counsel connections to facilitate new processes such as pre-ﬁling agreements and industry issue resolution projects; reaching out to other agencies (US Trustee; US Attorney; Social Security Administration; Financial Management Services), and collaborating success- fully with other functional areas in Counsel on litigation, and other types of work products. The employee’s performance should signiﬁcantly exceed what is expected of an employee of the same grade level.
Number: 5 awards (three legal and two non-legal)
Eligibility: All Counsel

Award Criteria: This award recognizes outstanding support of internal clients as well as the Office’s client, the IRS. Nominees for this award are exemplary and provide outstanding customer service. Speciﬁcally, candidates must demonstrate a high degree of prompt and professional service, possess outstanding interpersonal skills, a command of the subject matter, and signiﬁcantly contribute to the efficiency of the Office. The employee’s should signiﬁcantly exceed what is expected of an employee of the same grade level.

Training Awards
Number: 2 awards
Eligibility: All attorneys who instructed in-house, classroom training programs lasting than two days as part of an instructor cadre

Award Criteria: Candidates are nominated by an Associate or Division Counsel. Nominees will be considered by the board appointed by the Chief Counsel. This award recognizes out- standing platform skills, as well as outstanding abilities in the creation of highly effective presentations and adult learning theories.
Outstanding Mentor Award – Chief Counsel William E. Nelson Award

Award Criteria: This award recognizes employees who demonstrate exceptional mentoring capabilities, and outstanding efforts toward fostering growth and development in fellow employees. For example, showing the ability to recognize an individual’s potential, assisting them in applying their gifts and talents in ways that inspire conﬁdence with noticeable im- provement in performance.
